title: Defensive Positions Explained
description: Learn about defensive positions and how they stop the offense

sections.title: Meet the Defense
sections.content: The defense tries to stop the offense from scoring. They have 11 players with different jobs - let's learn about each position.

sections.title: Defensive Line (DL)
sections.content: The big guys up front who rush the quarterback and stop running plays.
details: Rush the quarterback on pass plays
Stop running backs at the line
Include Defensive Ends (DE) and Defensive Tackles (DT)

sections.title: Linebackers (LB)
sections.content: The middle level of defense - they cover running backs and tight ends while also helping stop the run.
details: Cover running backs and tight ends
Can rush the quarterback or drop into coverage

sections.title: Cornerbacks (CB)
sections.content: These are the fast defenders who cover wide receivers and defend against passes.

sections.title: Safeties (S)
sections.content: The last line of defense - they help with deep passes and provide run support.
details: Usually 2 safeties: Free Safety (FS) and Strong Safety (SS)
Strong Safety helps with run support
Both can cover receivers and tight ends

sections.title: Defensive Levels
sections.content: Defense works in three levels: the line (rush and stop runs), linebackers (middle coverage), and secondary (deep coverage).

sections.title: Defense Wins Games
sections.content: Each defensive position has a specific role, but they all work together to stop the offense and get the ball back for their team.
keyTakeaways: DL rushes QB and stops runs up front
LB covers middle areas and supports run defense
CB covers receivers and defends passes
S provides deep help and run support

questions.question: Which defensive position primarily covers wide receivers?
questions.explanation: Cornerbacks are the primary defenders who cover wide receivers and defend against passes.

questions.question: What is the main job of the defensive line?
questions.explanation: The defensive line's main jobs are to rush the quarterback and stop running plays at the line.

questions.question: How many levels does the defense typically have?
questions.explanation: Defense has three levels: defensive line, linebackers, and secondary (cornerbacks and safeties).

questions.question: Linebackers only defend against the pass.
questions.explanation: False. Linebackers both defend against passes and help stop running plays.
